At the Nation's Table: Zuni, N.M.;
A Seed Bank For Sacred Corn
description: For generations, members of the Zuni tribe in western New Mexico have used a mixture of ground corn, turquoise and other ingredients tucked into a buckskin pouch for religious ceremonies, sprinkling a pinch into a fire to feed the family ancestors.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about price-fixing and fraud investigations involving the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company misstated the legal status of talks between a former executive of the company, Mark E. Whitacre, and the Justice Department. There has been no plea bargain agreement between them. A corrective article appears today on page D1.

title: International Multifoods (IMC,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included net gain of $ 500,000 from the sale of the company's surimi seafood business and the favorable impact of a tax settlement, and offset by a write-down of computer software in the vending distribution business and corporate restructuring costs. Excluding the unusual items, net income in the second quarter was $ 6.5 million, or 36 cents a share.c-Included net gain of $ 25.9 million from the sale of the company's frozen specialty foods business, and offset by costs associated with the integration of the acquired food service distribution business of Leprino Foods Company. Excluding the unusual items, net income in the quarter was $ 5.5 million, or 30 cents a share.

title: High Court to Hear Case on Government's Refusal to Adjust Census
description: Entering a long-running dispute over the 1990 census, the Supreme Court today agreed to review the Government's refusal to adjust the census results to correct an acknowledged undercount that missed a disproportionate number of black and Hispanic residents of large cities.

title: Alison Steele, Disk Jockey, Dies; The Pioneer 'Nightbird' Was 58
description: Alison Steele, whose sultry voice and iron will helped her become one of the first women in the country to be hired as a disk jockey, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 58.

title: National Data Corp.(NDC,N) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Aug 31
President of American Express Abruptly Resigns
description: In a surprise move, Jeffrey E. Stiefler, president of the American Express Company, abruptly tendered his resignation yesterday, telling the company he was leaving at the end of the month.

title: Helene Curtis Industries(HC,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 31
For Pataki, Popularity Is Found To Be Still Lagging in Voter Poll
description: Gov. George E. Pataki finished his ninth month in office with his popularity still lagging among the state's voters, particularly those in New York City, according to a poll released today.

title: SENATE G.O.P. PLAN FOR MEDICARE USES BENEFIT CUTBACKS
description: The Congressional Budget Office said today that Senate Republican proposals to overhaul Medicare would achieve their goal of saving $270 billion in seven years not so much through innovative health policies as through the time-tested techniques of curbing payments to doctors and hospitals and raising costs to beneficiaries.

title: Bank's Law Firm Gave Papers At Heart of Suit to Magazine
description: In a case brought by Bankers Trust Company seeking to prevent Business Week magazine from publishing information from sealed documents, a law firm that represents the bank said it had provided the documents to the magazine.

title: Riley Pulls a Big Man Off Bench
description: Pat Riley, it turns out, wound up just like the rest of us. Besides a salary-like per diem and 10 percent of the company stock, all he wanted was a couple of guys who could shoot.

title: Bank Can't Lend to U.N.
description: After officials here said this week that the United Nations was exploring the possibility of obtaining loans from the World Bank to ease the organization's financial crisis, the World Bank said today that its rules would not permit such lending.

title: Corel Corp.(COSFF,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 318,000 on foreign exchange.c-Included a gain of $ 2,000 on foreign exchange.

title: No Tyson, No King: Round 1 to Mathis
description: Mike Tyson missed his flight from Cleveland, Don King was at jury selection downtown in his Federal fraud trial, so Buster Mathis Jr. was left at a midtown restaurant to hype his Nov. 4 fight against the former heavyweight champion.

title: RCSB Financial Inc. reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a $ 22,394,000 pretax gain on the sale of a unit.

title: Rapid Gains Are Reported On Genome
description: Researchers are reporting rapid progress in deciphering the human genome, the DNA library carried in each human cell.

title: Oxford Industries(OXM,N) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Sept 1
description: b-Included a 31 cent a share charge for environmental remediation. Before the charge, the company had net income of $ 2,978,000, or 34 cents a share.

title: Economic Scene; An argument that big ego is behind a lot of mergers.
description: FIRST they put them together and then, most notably in the cases of ITT, Sears and AT&T, they take them apart. Is there more behind the recent frenzy of corporate coupling and uncoupling than the restless ambition of managers and their investment bankers?

title: Micron Electronics Inc. reports earnings for 4th qtr to Aug 31
description: The above results reflected the combined operations of Micron Computer Inc. and Micron Custom Manufacturing Services Inc. prior to the April 7, 1995 merger of Micron Computer and Micron Custom with ZEOS International Ltd., and the combined operations of the company subsequent to the merger.On a pro-forma basis, which shows results as if the merger had occurred at the beginning of the periods presented, the 1994 quarter's net income was $ 10,666,000, or 11 cents a share, on sales of $ 210,092,000.Also on a pro-forma basis, the 1995 year's net income was $ 65,980,000, or 71 cents a share, on sales of $ 1,193,330,000, compared with net income of $ 25,191,000, or 28 cents a share, on sales of $ 650,983,000, in the 1994 year.

title: Apogee Enterprises Inc.(APOG,NNM) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Sept 2
People
description: * Ronnie Cohen was named president of Ayer Direct, New York, a unit of N. W. Ayer & Partners that was formerly known as Worldwide One on One. She succeeds Len Short, who left to join Charles Schwab & Co., San Francisco, as head of internal advertising and brand management. Ms. Cohen was previously an executive vice president and director of marketing and business development at Wunderman Cato Johnson, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. * Anthony R. Brescia was named to the new position of group account director for the BellSouth account at Merkley Newman Harty, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group. He was previously an executive vice president and senior account director at BBDO Worldwide, New York, also part of Omnicom.

title: Now, It's Saks For the Home
description: SAKS FIFTH AVENUE may not sell furniture, but it has just come out with its first home furnishings catalogue. It features small rugs, mirrors, lamps, gifts, occasional tables, linens, china and glassware. One bargain is a $90 hooked-wool rug (left), 30 by 40 inches, with apples and pears. It was designed by a Wisconsin artist, Tracy Porter. Catalogues, free, are available by calling (800) 345-3454.

title: Hunt Manufacturing (HUN,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 3
description: b-Included a provision of $ 1.6 million, or 6 cents a share, related to relocation and consolidation expenses. Before the charge, net income was $ 4,673,000, or 29 cents a share.Hunt Manufacturing said its latest third quarter comprised 14 weeks, compared with 13 weeks for the year-ago period, which ended Aug. 28.

title: Devils Sign Niedermayer to Three-Year Contract
description: One down, two to go. That's how the Devils felt today after signing of Scott Niedermayer to a new three-year deal, leaving goaltender Martin Brodeur and Claude Lemieux, the most valuable player of the Stanley Cup playoffs, still without contracts.

title: McCormick & Co.  (MCCRK,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
Miller Draft Said To Stay With Bates
description: The Miller Brewing Company has decided that its Miller Genuine Draft beer account, with billings estimated at $75 million, will remain at the Bates U.S.A. unit of Bates Worldwide in New York, advertising executives with knowledge of the decision said yesterday.

title: Accounts
description: * Uniroyal Tires, Greenville, S.C., owned by Michelin, to Trone Advertising, Greensboro, N.C., to handle its account, previously handled by Wyse Advertising, Cleveland. The billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

title:
Grozny Journal;
Mirth in Chechnya Amid the Anger of the Guns
description: Nadiya Semenakin surveyed the wretchedness around her -- her apartment, only recently laid with parquet for her husband's retirement, now a fire-swept concrete shell; the 16-story building across the street, its top floors dangling.

title: Bridge
description: Almost all the great players of the past have remained mentally alert to the end of their lives and some, like Oswald Jacoby, Waldemar Von Zedtwitz and B. Jay Becker, were able to win major titles at an advanced age. Charles Goren was the only conspicuous exception to this generalization.

title: Libyan Refugee Camp Stirs Concern on Ouster of Palestinians
description: The eviction by Libya of thousands of foreign workers prompted new concerns here today as United Nations officials reported that the Libyan Government was establishing a makeshift refugee camp to house as many as 1,500 newly deported Palestinians.

title: Losses From Hurricane Total $875 Million
description: Hurricane Marilyn has caused $875 million in losses for United States insurers as a result of its path through the United States Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico on Sept. 15 and 16, the Insurance Information Institute said yesterday.

title: McDowell's Backache Is a Headache
description: Jack McDowell was supposed to throw a baseball for the first time in six days today to test a strained muscle in his back that has bothered him for almost a month. Instead, McDowell underwent a bone scan to determine if he had a stress fracture and if that was stagnating any potential progress.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING Briton Wins Pursuit

title: School Board Seeking Inquiry Into Statements by Goldstein
description: When a mathematics professor formally asked Leon M. Goldstein, president of Kingsborough Community College, to approve the reappointment of a professor several years ago, Mr. Goldstein responded: "What's in it for me?" according to the professor.

title: INSIDE
description: C.I.A. to Discipline Officials Over Guatemala

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: S.E.C. Seeks to Assure Investors of Benefits The S.E.C., 20 years after Congress mandated competition in securities markets, is seeking to make it work for investors' benefit. The commission would require that stock markets give investors a reasonable chance of getting better prices than they often have.

title: Coach Gets 17 Years for Rape
description: PAUL HICKSON, Britain's head swimming coach at the 1988 Seoul Olympics, was jailed for 17 years yesterday for raping two women and indecently assaulting 13 while coaching them at school and college.

title: Calendar: Flower Show And Seasonal Festivals
description: Flower Competitions Planting Fields Arboretum, Planting Fields Road, Oyster Bay, L.I.; (516) 922-9200, or on weekends, (516) 922-9201.

title: Reform of the U.N. Is Overdue
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who can be diplomatic to a fault, cut quickly to the point in his address before the 50th anniversary session of the United Nations General Assembly this week. To win back the ebbing trust and support of Americans, he told the delegates, the U.N. must reform its financial ways.

title: Sports of The Times; Clean Slate For Maxwell In Philly
description: Vernon Maxwell spent most of yesterday afternoon looking at houses. Accompanied by his wife, Resharita, Maxwell explored neighborhood after neighborhood in Philadelphia. What struck him was an air of toughness about the city. Philadelphia was nothing like Houston, where he had spent the last four seasons playing with the Rockets. It was not like San Antonio, where he played most of his first two seasons.

title: Moon's Charity Is Questioned
description: Far more money goes to keeping WARREN MOON's Crescent Moon Foundation afloat than gets into the hands of students, an Associated Press review of the charity's 1989-93 tax returns shows. Financial records for 1994 were not available.

title: Bond Prices Are Steadied By a Strong Note Auction
description: Treasury prices recovered in late trading yesterday, paring losses after an auction of new five-year notes turned out better than expected.

title: Tenet Healthcare Corp.(THC,N) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Excluding gains on sales of facilities, earnings were 29 cents a share.c-Excluding gains on sales, earnings were 28 cents a share.Year ago results are for Tenet's predecessor company, National Medical Enterprises Inc.

title: Dollar Sells Off With Bonds, But Regains Some of Its Losses
description: The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday, dragged down by an early selloff in the United States bond market.

title: Primary Candidates, Shortchanged
description: Congress made sure there would be plenty of money for the Presidential public financing system in 1996 when it raised the voluntary tax checkoff a year ago from $1 to $3. Yet thanks to an absurd accounting rule imposed in 1991 by President Bush's Treasury Department, the Federal Election Commission expects a shortfall in the Federal matching funds that candidates had hoped to receive in January. The Republicans in particular are counting on this transfusion to get them through the critical first stages of the primary season.

title: A 'Piecemeal' Peace
description: After a second agreement between the warring parties on the principles for governing Bosnia, the gulf between the content of an American peace plan and the situation on the ground is large enough to suggest that the process is increasingly vulnerable.

title: Wausau Paper Mills Co.(WSAU,NNM) reports earnings for 4th qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 1 million, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.The share figures reflected a 10 percent stock dividend paid in January 1995.Wausau Paper Mills attributed its lower earnings in the latest fourth quarter and fiscal year to substantially higher pulp costs, which were up almost 70 percent over the course of the year.The paper company also cited weak demand for Rhinelander's specialty technical products in the second half. Wausau said efforts to raise selling prices, reduce costs and increase shipments were not enough to completely offset the higher pulp costs.''We see signs of Rhinelander's business improving and the pulp market stabilizing, though pulp is still in an upward trend,'' the company said. ''Both are keys to profit growth for Wausau papers.'' Wausau said shipments rose 5 percent in the latest fourth quarter to a record 97,000 tons.

title: Schnitzer Steel Ind.(SCHN,NNM) reports earnings for 4th qtr to Aug 31
Congressional Roundup; Immigration Curbs Voted
description: Turning aside pleas that it would be helping to break up families, the House Judiciary Committee today approved a measure severely restricting the ability of grown children of American citizens to immigrate to the United States.

title: Micron Technology (MU,N) reports earnings for 4th qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 29 million on the merger transaction.The share and per share figures reflected a 2-for-1 stock split in May.

title: Marriott Intl.(MAR,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 8
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.Sales are total sales.The results included 12 weeks of operations.

title: FRONTIER CORPORATION TO TAKE EARNINGS CHARGE
description: The Frontier Corporation plans to take a third-quarter charge of $112.2 million, or about 72 cents a share, to accelerate the depreciation of aging equipment. The Rochester-based telephone company also said it planned to take after-tax charges of $75 million to $85 million, or as much as 53 cents a share, to reflect severance costs and other expenses associated with the acquisition of ALC Communications Inc. and several other long-distance companies this year. Frontier said the extraordinary accounting charge was designed to reflect the quicker obsolescence of copper wiring and older switching systems in its telecommunications network. Six of the regional Bell operating companies have taken similar measures.

title: Culbro Corp.(CUC,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 2
description: b-Net loss and included a $ 3.6 million nonrecurring pretax charge in the Connecticut real estate business to write off development costs expended in earlier years for certain discontinued projects and a charge of $ 400,000 to close a facility in the industrial products business.(Loss)

title: From the Mind Of an Architect And Thinker
description: RARELY can one study an architect's creative process, but that's the purpose of an exhibition opening tonight at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Congressional efforts to curb immigration referred incorrectly to the arrival of Lourdes Rivera, whose case was used as an example of people on waiting lists to become citizens. Ms. Rivera and her two sisters entered the United States in 1983 and overstayed their tourist visas, becoming illegal immigrants; they did not enter the country illegally.

title: Kaufman & Broad Home Corp.(KBH,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
Restoring the Children's Zoo, Seriously; Fairy Tales Are Out, Unless Fairies Really Exist and Have Tails
description: In the golden dew of municipal memory, the Central Park Children's Zoo remains a toddler's paradise, a place where goats, ducklings, a talking crow and other child-sized beasts roamed amid fairy-tale sculptures.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the views of Quebec's youths on an Oct. 30 referendum calling for separation from Canada referred incorrectly at one point to the side that is behind in the polls. It is the side favoring separation.

title: Classical, Strictly
description: COULD it be the influence of his cousin the Prince of Wales? The designer David Linley says no, but his new wood desk accessories, including a $125 walnut column pencil pot, are strictly classical in inspiration. English craftsmen make the pieces by hand in English hardwoods. Available next month at Alfred Dunhill stores. For information: (800) 776-4053.

title: It's No More Baby-Sitting for Green: The Mets Are His Baby Now
description: Jason Isringhausen was walking out of the Mets' clubhouse before yesterday's doubleheader, when he caught the eye of Manager Dallas Green, who was holding court with reporters.

title: Research Network on Cancer
description: The New Jersey State Commission on Cancer Research and the State Department of Health plan to establish a statewide cancer registry network that will be made available free to all hospitals in the state, health officials announced yesterday. A $52,000 grant from the Fannie E. Rippel Foundation will pay for computer software and training for hospital workers using the system and researchers collecting the data, the officials said.

title: House G.O.P. Plans Vote on Bank-Securities Law
description: The House Republican leadership tentatively agreed tonight to vote this fall on legislation aimed at eliminating the legal barriers separating the nation's banking and securities industries, Congressional aides said..

title: Lawyer for Colombia's Chief Wounded in Ambush
description: A group of armed men this morning attacked a car carrying the lawyer who has defended President Ernesto Samper during a congressional investigation into whether the President knowingly accepted campaign contributions from drug traffickers.

title: Clampdown at Border Is Hailed as Success
description: Border Patrol agents call it squeezing the balloon. For the past year, aided by a big infusion of Federal money, manpower and technology, they have been squeezing as never before, choking off illegal crossings from Mexico at the busiest section of the border.

title: Microsoft-Visa On-Line Plan Draws the Ire of Competitors
description: Microsoft and Visa International proposed an industry software standard for on-line payments and financial transactions yesterday, but opposition from key companies could lead to a standards war that impedes the rollout of electronic commerce over the Internet.

title: The Mob's Tale of Sorrow About Las Vegas
description: CASINO Love and Honor in Las Vegas By Nicholas Pileggi 363 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: Jones Talks to N.F.L. Owners
description: Jerry Jones, the Dallas Cowboys' owner, met for four and a half hours in Washington yesterday with Commissioner Paul Tagliabue, some fellow owners and several lawyers to discuss his rogue sponsorship deals with Nike, Pepsi and Dr Pepper.

title: Former Essex Official Admits Kickback Role at Housing Site
description: The former Register of Essex County pleaded guilty today to accepting kickbacks and conspiring to use her influence as a director of a low-income housing complex to award millions of dollars in contracts to security guard companies.

title: How Lawyers Can Regain the Public's Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Norand Corp.(NRND,NNM) reports earnings for 4th qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included charges and operating losses totaling $ 8.2 million, or $ 1.05 a share, associated with the company's Italian unit, and a gain of $ 3.5 million, or 45 cents a share, on a favorable settlement reached with the Internal Revenue Service over prior years' tax returns.c-Net income(Loss)

title: British Court to Seek Trader's Extradition
description: A British magistrates court has summoned the former Barings trader Nicholas W. Leeson to face fraud charges by bondholders of the collapsed Barings P.L.C. in what represents the former trader's last chance to return to Britain. Two weeks ago the Serious Fraud Office turned down a request by Mr. Leeson to plead guilty to fraud charges in a British court to avoid extradition to Singapore.

title: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.(GAP,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Sept 9
How Lawyers Can Regain the Public's Respect; To Change Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: As Bosnian Army Takes Serb-Held Town, Protectors Become the Protected
description: Each evening, in an apartment on Ibre Hodzic Street, three women, two Serbs and one Muslim, gather around a radio to hear the evening news from Sarajevo.

title: C.I.A. May Dismiss Chief Officer Involved in Guatemala
description: Breaking with the past, the Central Intelligence Agency will dismiss, demote or discipline up to a dozen officers, including the former chief of covert operations in Latin America, for shielding suspect agents and stifling reports of human-rights abuses in Guatemala, Government officials said today.

title: Sudbury Inc.(SUDS,NNM) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Aug 31
description: Sudbury said that improved performance at its Wagner Castings Company unit and lower interest costs contributed to its first-quarter earnings growth.The company said Wagner Castings had sales growth of 14 percent during a relatively slow period for the automotive industry. Sudbury said it attributed Wagner Castings' performance to new business and its presence on vehicle platforms such as the Ford World Car and Chrysler minivans.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WAL-MART STORES INC., Bentonville, Ark., the nation's largest retailer, plans to cut about 1 percent of the employees at its headquarters to save money. About 80 to 100 people are expected to be laid off. DSC COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Plano, Tex., received a four-year $200 million contract to supply Nynex Corp. with fiber-optic communications systems. The contract extends a two-year agreement signed in 1993.

title: Stackhouse Signs With 76ers
description: The Philadelphia 76ers signed their top pick, JERRY STACKHOUSE, to a three-year contract. "The word to describe Jerry Stackhouse is 'ferocious,' " said JOHN LUCAS, the 76ers' coach and general manager.

title: A Little Whimsy Never Hurts
description: WE'RE trying to reflect the kind of spirit our children brought into our lives," said Steve Vaubel, a Brooklyn jeweler, who, with his wife, Anita, designs whimsical drawer pulls like "Boaters," left ($55). They have designed 80 pewter pulls that work on doors of all kinds (or as coat hooks). There are hippos and hares, tepees and melting skyscrapers, and even court jesters. Available at Inside/Out in East Hampton, L.I.; (516) 329-3600.

title: I.B.M. Plans to Consolidate OS/2 Development in Texas
description: In a move aimed at shoring up its struggling OS/2 operating system software, I.B.M. will relocate 1,100 software developers and other personnel from Boca Raton, Fla., to Austin, Tex., the company told employees yesterday.

title: MDS Health Group reports earnings for 3d qtr to July 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday about an agreement on the transfer of parts of the West Bank to Palestinian control misstated the deadline for the Palestinians to honor a pledge to remove from their charter articles calling for the destruction of Israel. The Palestinians' commitment is to amend the charter within two months after the inauguration of an elected Palestinian council, not within two years.

title: It's Folk Art In King Size
description: THE Fall Antiques Show is back at the Seventh Regiment Armory, on Park Avenue at 67th Street, where it began in 1979 (with tickets at $3.50 and Martha Stewart's debut as a big-time caterer). The show of 75 dealers of folk art, American antiques and decorative objects from the beginning of the century opens today and runs through Sunday.

title: Visitors to a Carnegie Without the Concrete
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra, the remains of several maple trees and a new season were on the agenda at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. What this distinguished ensemble played was very nearly upstaged by what they were playing on. I refer first to the phantom concrete substratum found under the stage this summer and subsequently removed, and then to the fresh new lumber that has been nailed over the void.

title: What Presence! What Prices!
description: SISTER PARISH once thought $40 was an appallingly high price for an upholstered chair. So, she probably would have been revolted to step into the salesrooms of Sotheby's and see the prices her own objects are expected to bring when they go on sale tomorrow morning.

title: Conservatives May Join Perot
description: If the New Jersey Conservative Party succeeds in getting 10 percent of the vote on the November ballot, the organization may change its name and affiliate with the party that Ross Perot says he intends to form, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Safeguards for Drinking Water
description: The House Resources Subcommittee on National Parks, Forests and Lands will take testimony today on legislation to buy more than 17,000 acres of privately owned land in Sterling Forest, which straddles the New Jersey-New York border, to preserve water sources. Water from the forest flows into reservoirs in North Jersey that supply drinking water to 1 in 4 New Jerseyans. One bill would allocate $17.5 million for the purchase. Another would set aside an additional $7.5 million.

title: AT HOME WITH: James Finn Garner; On Pens and Needles
description: THERE is a feel of 50's sitcom bliss to dinner time at James Finn Garner's house, one of dozens of narrow houses on a quiet street on Chicago's North Side. Mozart plays softly on the kitchen radio. Six-month-old Liam snoozes in a baby seat next to the dinner table. And Mr. Garner and his wife, Lies (pronounced "lease"), eat shish kebabs and discuss what went wrong with their garden.

title: How Lawyers Can Regain the Public's Respect; Unhappy Career Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: Neither Blisters Nor Brewers Stop Cone and Yanks
description: David Cone knew he could make life much simpler for David Cone this weekend if he pitched like David Cone today. His strategy was practical and obvious; his performance was precise and opportune. As a result, Cone may have earned himself and his weary Yankee teammates an important day off on Sunday.

title: G.O.P. and Clinton Reach Deal to Halt Federal Shutdown
description: Leaders of the Republican-controlled Congress today reached an agreement with the White House on a plan that will keep the Government from shutting down for lack of money next week while they try to thrash out differences over the 1996 Federal budget.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 FAMILIARITY BRED ACCORD Having been virtually locked up together for more than two months, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators found themselves bound in a common cause that required them to overcome ingrained hatreds to produce an agreement. A1 SOME WARMING WITH CHINA China told the United States that it had decided to cancel its contract to sell two nuclear-power reactors to Iran, but it declined an invitation from President Clinton for President Jiang Zemin to come to Washington next month. A1 LIBYA DEPORTS MORE PALESTINIANS Libya has expelled thousands of foreign workers, especially Palestinians, and the United Nations reports that Libya is building a border camp to house thousands more. A10 DISCIPLINE AT THE C.I.A. The C.I.A. will dismiss, demote or discipline up to a dozen officers for shielding suspect agents and stifling reports of human-rights abuses in Guatemala, officials said. A3 BOSNIA PLAN IS VULNERABLE News Analysis: The gulf between the content of the American peace initiative for Bosnia and the situation on the ground is large enough to suggest it is vulnerable. A12 NATO PROGRESS ON BOSNIA NATO diplomats said a committee was making progress on resolving how countries from outside the alliance could take part in any military operation to enforce a peace settlement in Bosnia. A13 Grozny Journal: Losing the war but keeping a sense of humor. A4 National A16-24, B9-12 MEDICARE PLAN ASSESSED The Congressional Budget Office said Senate Republicans would reach their goal of saving $270 billion in Medicare costs over seven years not so much by innovation as by the traditional methods of cutting payments to doctors and raising premiums. A1 SIMPSON TEAM'S TURN O. J. Simpson's chief lawyer opened his final argument to the jury, criticizing the state's case as a "rush to judgment" and an "obsession to win at all costs." A1 GOVERNMENT SHUTDOWN AVERTED Congressional leaders and the White House agreed on a plan to keep the Government from shutting down for lack of money when the fiscal year ends. A1 PAPAL LUNCH IN SOUP KITCHEN When Pope John Paul II has lunch after Mass in Oriole Park stadium, he will be joined at a soup kitchen by 20 participants in local Roman Catholic charity programs. A16 NEW CHASE ON BORDER A new 10-foot-high steel wall along the border with Mexico in California has given immigration agents an edge over border crossers but has not ended the cat-and-mouse game with them. A16 GREEN LIGHT FOR 'CLEAN CAR' The Environmental Protection Agency approved specifications for a "clean car" that could mean emission standards for 49 states far cleaner than the law requires. A16 JUSTICES TO REVIEW CENSUS The Supreme Court agreed to review the Government's refusal to adjust the 1990 census, which some large cities contend missed a disproportionate number of blacks and poor people. A18 PEROT TAKES ON CALIFORNIA Ross Perot began his effort to elect a third-party candidate by filing for a place on the ballot in California, one of the most daunting tasks such a candidate can face. B12 Metro Digest B1 MAYOR DEFENDS SCHOOLS CHOICE Mayor Giuliani offered his strongest defense yet of his choice for schools chancellor, Leon M. Goldstein, president of Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn, calling criticism of his political connections and qualifications "cheap shots and misinterpretations."A1 Business Digest D1 Arts/Entertainment C13-20 WRITERS ENCHANTED BY OPERA Leading contemporary writers are being drawn to opera as a capacious, flexible medium in which they can explore grand themes of history and politics. The libretto is again an art form of choice. C1 Philharmonic reports progress in contract talks. C13 'Murder One' slumps as the Simpson case draws more viewers. C20 Film: "Prince Brat and the Whipping Boy." C13 Music: The Philadelphians. C14 Whale and Blur. C16 The Pop Life C16 A night of guitar. C17 Dance: Maguy Marin. C13 Books: "Casino," by Nicholas Pileggi. C17 TV: "New York News." C13 David Frost interviews Gen. Colin Powell. C18 The Home Section C1-11 It's folk art in king size. C1 Sports B13-19 Baseball: Yanks inch closer to post-season. B13 Concern about McDowell. B13 Mets reward Green. B13 Columns: Rhoden on Vernon Maxwell. B13 Obituaries D22 Editorials/Op-Ed A26-27 Editorials Too high a price. Reform of the U.N. is overdue. Candidates, shortchanged. A new nation's first P.O.W.'s. Letters William Safire: New evil empire. Maureen Dowd: Grand funk railroad. Susana MacLean: The victim gets the blame in Central Park. Dorothy Nelkin: Biology is not destiny. Chronicle D28 Bridge C17 Crossword C14

title: Grady Sutton, 89, a Comic Foil to Fields, Hepburn and Lombard
description: Grady Sutton, one of W. C. Fields's favorite foils as a character actor in "The Bank Dick" and other films, died on Sept. 17 at the Motion Picture and Television Country Home and Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 89.

title: Writers Enchanted by the Freedom of Opera
description: After 21 novels, many volumes of poetry and essays, and at least 13 plays, Joyce Carol Oates has written the libretto for an opera, "Black Water," based on her novel about the Chappaquiddick incident. Doris Lessing so liked writing the libretto for her first opera, "The Making of the Representative for Planet 8," from her novel by the same name, that she has written a second opera, drawn from another of her novels, "The Marriages Between Zones Three, Four and Five."

title: James Grottola, 57, Printers' Local Head
description: James Grottola, the president of New York Typographical Union No. 6, died on Tuesday at his home in Commack, L.I. He was 57.

title: Threat Is Seen in Pension Shift
description: Escalating its opposition to a Republican plan to allow companies to use money from pension plans that have a minimum cushion of funds, the Clinton Administration contended today that passage of the measure would reduce the retirement security of millions of Americans, endanger the economy and inspire predatory corporate takeovers.

title: Market Place; The S.E.C. tries to insure that investors get better stock prices.
description: TWENTY years after Congress mandated competition among securities markets, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday made its most determined effort yet to make that competition work to the benefit of investors.

title: Whitman Denies Forcing Official Out
description: The Governor boasts in a speech that turning the Department of Motor Vehicles' district offices over to private management is working. The spokesman for the Department of Motor Vehicles bluntly contradicts her. The next day, the spokesman is dismissed.

title: Simpson's Lawyer Tells Jury That Evidence 'Doesn't Fit'
description: Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. repeatedly told jurors at the O. J. Simpson trial today that "if it doesn't fit, you must acquit." The chief defense lawyer was talking not just about an infamous leather glove, but the prosecution's entire case against the former football star.

title: Morrison Restaurants Inc.(RI,N) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Sept 2
description: b-Included a gain of $ 25.8 million, or 71 cents a share, from the sale and closing of certain education, business and industry contracts in its contract food service division, and a charge of $ 12 million, or 33 cents a share, from the conversion or closing of certain L&N Grills.

title: Gene Therapy Shows No Benefits in 2 Studies
description: Two rigorous studies of gene therapy have found that it failed to benefit patients with cystic fibrosis or Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

title: Shoney's Inc.(SHN,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 6
description: b-Included income of $ 2,034,000, or 5 cents a share, from discontinued operations.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 2,242,000, or 5 cents a share, and an extraordinary charge of $ 1,038,000, or 3 cents a share, for early extinguishment of debt.Some figures are rounded.

title: CULBRO CALLS OFF TALKS TO SELL GENERAL CIGAR
description: The Culbro Corporation said yesterday that it had ended talks to sell a 51 percent stake in its General Cigar unit to Tabacalera S.A. for $100 million. Culbro, the New York-based maker of Garcia y Vega and Tiparillo cigars, rejected the transaction because of differences over management, said A. Ross Wollen, Culbro vice president. The company's shares fell to $6 early yesterday, but closed at $40, up $1, on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Wollen said the company "intends to examine alternatives" to selling the cigar unit. Tabacalera, which controls 63 percent of Spain's tobacco market, has been looking for new markets abroad.

title: The Pop Life
description: Letting It Out in the Lyrics

title: Rhodes Inc.(RHD,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 31
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about a conference on genetics and criminal behavior misstated the political views of Support Coalition, a self-described "psychiatric survivors liberation movement" whose members participated in a protest. It says it is nonpartisan, not Marxian.

title: Throwing a Tantrum Out of Sheer Giddiness
description: Throwing a Tantrum Out of Sheer Giddiness It was a battle between the geeks and the brats when Whale and Blur performed a sold-out concert on Tuesday night at the Academy. Whale is a self-consciously awkward group of students from Sweden playing a mix of new-wave, punk and funk with studied stiffness. Blur, from England, mixes new-wave, punk and pop, topping it all with a lead singer who delivers his lines like a child throwing a tantrum, though not because he's angry but because he's giddy.

title: Stock Prices Take a Wild Ride Down but Rebound at Close
description: Led by technology issues, stock prices tumbled sharply enough yesterday to set off the New York Stock Exchange's 50-point "circuit breaker" rule, but bounced back before the close.

title: E.P.A. Backs Plan to Allow Cleaner Cars In Most States
description: The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency today approved specifications for a "clean car" that, if it wins support from auto makers and officials in New York and Massachusetts, could result in emission standards for 49 states far cleaner than Federal rules require but not quite as clean as what some of the states are planning.

title: Isles Keep Options Open on Redden, Top Prospect
description: Ask Wade Redden if he thinks he is ready to play in the National Hockey League right now and he will give you a forthright answer.

title: Religious Differences Aside, 2 Men Await Pope's Soup Kitchen Visit
description: For two years now, they have eaten breakfast together each morning at Our Daily Bread, this city's largest soup kitchen, and most days, the hour passes with only the mildest of chitchat. Once in a while, though, Douglas Tillery and his friend Alphonso Alvarez Jr. start talking religion. Then look out.

title: Guilty Plea in Bank Holdup
description: Martin Ernesto Rivas, an illegal alien from El Salvador living in Scotch Plains, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to robbing a bank in Westfield of $3,922 on July 21, The Associated Press reported. He acknowledged, but did not specifically plead to, robbing another bank in Scotch Plains of $547 on July 18. In both instances, he gave a teller a note and displayed what appeared to be a bomb, but it was only paper, tape and wire, said Aidan P. O'Connor, an Assistant United States Attorney.

title: Arrow International Inc.(ARRO,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CISCO SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY GRAND JUNCTION NETWORKS
description: Cisco Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the privately held Grand Junction Networks Inc. in a stock swap valued about $348 million based on Tuesday's closing price of Cisco, which was $68. Grand Junction makes Fast Ethernet and Ethernet desktop switching products, which allow information to be passed around on a network of personal computers. The acquisition would give Cisco, the largest maker of equipment for computer networks, a broader line of hubs and switches used to route information. Cisco said it would exchange five million of its shares to acquire Grand Junction. Grand Junction employs 85 people at its headquarters in Fremont, Calif.

title: No Headline
description: "It's completely thrilling to hear people sing your words. For a poet, it's what poetry is all about. It's empowering -- 50 people in an orchestra, 3,000 people in a room. The words are carried on ethereal wings!" THULANI DAVIS, the poet and playwright, on writing operas. [ C18:3. ]

title: Green and Johnson Manage To Survive
description: Dallas Green, New Wave manager. Davey Johnson, hot commodity.

title: Nu Horizons Electronics Corp.(NUHC,NNM) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 31
Korean Grocer Is Killed in Failed Holdup
description: Sung Ju Hung left his native South Korea six years ago, having the same dreams that are shared by many of his fellow immigrants: to work hard enough so that someday he would be able to buy his own grocery store.

title: Sun Television & Appliances Co.(SNTV,NNM) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 26
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $ 532,000 on the sale of property.

title: Super Rite Corp. reports earnings for 2d qtr to Sept 2
description: Super Rite said improved performance in the wholesale and retail segments increased earnings in the latest quarter.

title: Counterfeit Clothing
description: In raids on factories, warehouses and shops in New York City and Los Angeles, customs agents attacked a Korean organized crime ring that manufactured clothing, handbags and sporting goods overseas for sale here under counterfeit labels.

title: Turner Pay Pact Said to Top $100 Million
description: Ted Turner claims he has no trouble playing second fiddle. That's small wonder. In the orchestra Time Warner is creating, second fiddle can pay a whole lot more than first violin.

title: Drug Firms at Odds Over Patent Extensions
description: By the time the Senate Finance Committee resumes consideration of the Federal budget's multibillion dollar issues Thursday, some of the nation's largest drug companies will have spent and lobbied heavily against one amendment that hardly amounts to budget dust.

title: A 20-Year Sentence for 1982 Chelsea Killing
description: A New Jersey businessman implicated on videotape by a dead accomplice 13 years after a grisly Chelsea murder was sentenced yesterday to a minimum of 20 years in prison.

title: Quality Food Centers (QFCI,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 9
description: Quality Food Centers Inc. said its latest third quarter results included about $ 2.9 million in added interest expense related to its March 29, 1995 recapitalization. The company said the number of shares outstanding for the latest third quarter decreased due to the recapitalization.

title: Rutgers Gets Indiana Transfer
description: ROB HODGSON, the third leading scorer in New York State history with 2,532 points, has decided to transfer from Indiana University and attend Rutgers, where he will play for Coach BOB WENZEL as a freshman this season. The 6-foot-7-inch Hodgson, who can play small forward and shooting guard, averaged 29.7 points, 15.2 rebounds and 3.7 assists as a senior at William Floyd High School in Shirley, L.I., two seasons ago.

title: Excerpts of Closing Arguments on Murder Charges Against O. J. Simpson
description: Following are closing arguments, excerpted by topic, by Deputy District Attorney Christopher A. Darden, and by the chief defense lawyer, Johnnie L. Cochran Jr., given yesterday in Los Angeles in the trial of O. J. Simpson in the slayings of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Lennar Corp.(LEN,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included gains on real estate sales of 3 cents a share in the latest third quarter, compared with 14 cents a share a year ago.

title: In Haiti, Democracy, Not Aristide, Is on Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Donaldson Co.(DCI,N) reports earnings for 4th qtr to July 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 2,206,000, or 8 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Article 495995 -- No Title
description: Ben Franklin, unlike a lot of public figures here, is moving to the left. He is also losing his fur collar on the new issue of the $100 bill -- the first fully redesigned paper denomination since 1928 -- which was shown today by the Treasury.

title: Hidden Change in Foreign Aid Bill Sets G.O.P. Against G.O.P.
description: A disagreement has broken out among Senate Republicans over an amendment quietly stuck into the foreign aid bill that would withdraw most-favored-nation trading status to any country that does not back sanctions against the Burmese military Government.

title: A History Lesson: The Politicization of Giuliani
description: THERE are times, given the public's notoriously short memory, when a history lesson is in order. This seems like one of those times, what with a Republican Mayor embracing a loyal confederate of the Brooklyn Democratic organization in his quest for control of the school system, a candidate for schools chancellor better known for his politics than his scholarship.

title: New Plan Realty Trust (NPR,N) reports earnings for Year to Jul 31
description: b-Included a $ 228,000 gain on the sale of properties.c-Included a $ 460,000 gain on the sale of properties and a $ 530,000 gain on the sale of securities.

title: Congressional Roundup; Service Program Set Back
description: On a near-party-line vote of 55 to 45, the Republican-controlled Senate today approved an $80.9 billion spending bill for veterans and housing programs that would eliminate one of President Clinton's major initiatives, the national service program known as Americorps.

title: Hartco Enterprises reports earnings for 2d qtr to July 29
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Giuliani, Irked, Hardens Defense Of Choice for Schools Chancellor
description: In an intensified defense of his latest choice of Leon M. Goldstein to be New York City's schools chancellor, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday called criticism of Mr. Goldstein's political connections "cheap shots and misinterpretations."

title: N.F.L. Recalls a Compassionate Steinberg
description: Much of the pro football world -- players, coaches and executives -- paid a final tribute today to Dick Steinberg, the former Jets general manager. Steinberg died Monday of stomach cancer at age 60.

title: Where to Find It
description: FOR a while in the late 1980's, when compact disks and CD players swiftly saturated the audio market, record turntables appeared destined for the same fate as manual typewriters and rotary-dial telephones. That never happened, much to the delight of audiophiles who insist that vinyl records offer a richer sound than CD's and to the cheers of music lovers with irreplaceable record collections.

title: MORRISON RESTAURANTS PLANS THREE-WAY SPLIT
description: Morrison Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that it planned to split into three separate public companies. The three companies would be Ruby Tuesday Inc., the renamed parent company, which would also operate a specialty restaurant business; Morrison Fresh Cooking Inc., a family dining business; and Morrison Health Care Inc., a health-care contract-feeding business. The parent company, would be based in Mobile, Ala. Morrison common stockholders would receive one Morrison Health Care share for every three Morrison shares held and one Morrison Fresh Cooking share for every four Morrison shares. Shareholders would receive one common Ruby Tuesday share for every two Morrison shares. The company's stock jumped $2.50 yesterday to $20.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: NATO Sees Progress on Formula to Let Russia Join Bosnia Force
description: NATO diplomats said today that a committee was making progress on resolving the issue of how countries from outside the alliance could take part in any military operation to enforce a peace settlement in Bosnia.

title: Wolverine World Wide Inc.(WWW,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 9
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 70,000.

title: Trudging in Beckett's Vacuum
description: The 10 grim but bawdy gray-faced dancers who shuffle along in Maguy Marin's "May B" are not happy campers. They are, rather, fugitives from the bleak world of Samuel Beckett, to whom Ms. Marin, a French choreographer, pays an uncanny right-minded tribute.

title: Company Accused of Fraud In School's Asbestos Cleanup
description: An environmental consulting company based in Manhattan, its president and its laboratory director have been indicted on larceny and fraud charges after falsely certifying that a school in Woodside, Queens, had been cleared of asbestos, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday.

title: Convicted Killer Admits Slaying Woman, 78
description: In a move that surprised even his own lawyer, Reginald McFadden pleaded guilty to murder yesterday, telling a Nassau County judge that he killed a 78-year-old woman in a rage after he got lost walking to a railroad station.

title: China Cancels A Sale to Iran, Pleasing U.S.
description: In a move that is likely to speed up the recovery in the troubled relationship between Washington and Beijing, China told the United States today that it had decided to cancel its contract to sell two nuclear power reactors to Iran.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Passion That Whips the Blood
description: This is the week the bloodthirsty chess world has been waiting for. After eight consecutive draws between the world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, and the challenger, Viswanathan Anand -- an unprecedented streak of standoffs -- the two men traded victories, concluding the first half of their 20-game match with the fireworks that had been anticipated from the start.

title: G.O.P. Pushes Medical Savings Accounts to Replace Health Insurance
description: One of the rules of thumb of personal finance is that consumers should buy insurance only against expenses they could not easily afford. Another rule, of course, is that people should set money aside for rainy days.

title: Samsonite Corp. reports earnings for 2d qtr to July 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss associated with the extinguishment of debt of $ 8,042,000.Excluding the effects of the amortization of reorganization value in excess of identifiable assets, nonrecurring holding company expenses and extraordinary items, the company had net income of $ 4,567,000, or 29 cents a share, in the latest quarter, and $ 3,352,000, or 22 cents a share, in year-ago period.(Loss)

title: Harry D. Goldman, 92, Judge Who Named Monitors for Attica
description: Harry D. Goldman, a retired judge who appointed monitors to protect inmates at Attica prison after a riot in which more than 40 people were killed, died on Thursday at his home in Rochester. He was 92.

title: Now David Frost Takes His Turn With Powell
description: David Frost makes his contribution tomorrow night to the Colin L. Powell book-promoting, candidacy-testing campaign. It's an amiable encounter, with a view of the White House, that produces no revelations but that confirms General Powell's ability to be steadily engaging and calculatedly above the season's political squabblings. (A confession of reviewer identification: The French version of "My American Journey" is titled "L'Enfant du Bronx," which is what I am, too.)

title: End Seen for Rule That AT&T Must Disclose Its Price Plans
description: The Federal Communications Commission plans to free the AT&T Corporation from the last vestiges of price regulation, in exchange for commitments from the company to protect rates for low-income customers and people in remote rural areas, agency officials said today.

title: Ameron Inc.(AMN,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
Gencorp Inc.(GY,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
description: Gencorp said sales growth occurred in all three business segments; automotive, polymer products, and Aerojet, the company's aerospace and defense segment.

title: Scholastic Corp.(SCHL,NNM) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Aug 31
description: (Loss)

title: Battle Over Bonanza For Drug Companies
description: An army of lobbyists has been enlisted to do battle in Congress over a provision in an international trade treaty that has created a windfall for the makers of patent drugs.

title: No One Advocates Bad Bilingual Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Transat AT reports earnings for 3d qtr to Jul 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2.5 million, or 20 cents a share, on the transfer of incoming tour operator functions from Vacances Air Transat to a joint-venture.Results are in Canadain dollars.

title: What Sent the Nearings To a Wilderness Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Material Sciences Corp.(MSC,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 31
Gtech Holdings Corp.(GTK,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 26
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,846,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: A Mets Story: Two Rookie Pitchers Triumph in Sweep
description: Robert Person thought his dream of pitching in the major leagues was finally going to come true Tuesday night when he was scheduled to be the Mets' starter against the Cincinnati Reds. But a steady drizzle soaked Shea Stadium, forcing a postponement and making Person wait until yesterday to make his big-league debut.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Whither Humphrey, the cat who lives at 10 Downing Street? London newspapers and television newscasts were filled with reports this week of the presumed death and then the reappearance of Humphrey, Prime Minister John Major's premier mouser.

title: N.L. West Seesaw Tips To Dodgers
description: Dodgers 7, Rockies 4 Eric Karros homered and scored three times and Tim Wallach hit two sacrifice flies as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Colorado Rockies, 7-3, last night to reclaim a half-game lead in the National League West.

title: Flitch Captures Lawrence And Heads Home for Winter
description: The great gathering of horses for next month's Breeders' Cup continued yesterday at Belmont Park, where the 3-year-old colt Flitch restored some luster to his career by winning the 103d running of the Lawrence Realization.

title: For Mayor of Los Angeles, 2 Years and 19 Designers Later
description: It happened one summer day just as Polly Williams Kroeger was giving a tour of the Los Angeles Mayor's mansion, currently under renovation, to hospital officials who had hoped to use it for a party.

title: Simpson Trial Undermines 'Murder One'
description: In a case of life intimidating art, CNN's coverage of the closing prosecution arguments in the O. J. Simpson trial grabbed millions of additional viewers Tuesday night, some of whom were surely stolen away from ABC's "Murder One," the new drama series widely compared to the real-life Simpson case.

title: A Disney Division Selects Foote, Cone
description: The Disney Interactive division of the Walt Disney Company in Glendale, Calif., has named the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding to handle the creative part of the account for its Edutainment unit, which had been at Kresser Stein Robaire in Santa Monica, Calif., for the last year. The billings have not been determined.

title: Heilig-Meyers Co.(HMY,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 31
Suspended Principal Returns
description: The high school principal who was suspended after he was quoted in a newspaper article as referring to opponents of his policies as "some nasty bastards" will return to work today, and no further disciplinary action will be taken against him, the Superintendent of Glen Rock's schools, Dario Valacarcel, said yesterday. At a meeting of the Glen Rock Teachers Association yesterday, the principal, Lawrence Schein, acknowledged using "totally inappropriate language for which I am genuinely sorry" when he was interviewed for a Sept. 17 article in The Sunday Record of Hackensack.

title: Official From Boston Chicken Named I.B.M.'s Chief Strategist
description: Running a big computer company is no different from, say, running a successful fast-food chain, or at least that is what Louis V. Gerstner Jr. apparently believes. Yesterday, Mr. Gerstner, the chairman of I.B.M., named J. Bruce Harreld, the president of Boston Chicken Inc., to be I.B.M.'s chief strategist.

title: High Court to Rule if Lotus Could Copyright Commands
description: Accepting a case with important implications for the computer software industry, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Lotus Development Corporation had a valid copyright in the series of commands used to operate its pioneering Lotus 1-2-3 spreadsheet program.

title: Quick & Reilly Group Inc.(BQR,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 25
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding for the year-ago quarter were retroactively adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split paid on June 7.

title: Governor Backs Bond Campaign
description: With Gov. Christine Todd Whitman as their featured speaker, supporters of the $340 million Green Acres bond issue proposal kicked off their campaign yesterday on behalf of the land-preservation measure, which will be Question No. 4 on the November ballot. "We need to preserve our historic sites, our environmental resources and our farmlands as an investment in our physical, spiritual and economic health," the Governor said at a news conference at Monmouth Battlefield State Park.

title: Will Regulators Penalize Daiwa? No Answers Yet
description: By waiting nearly two months to tell regulators that it had learned of a $1.1 billion loss from unauthorized trading, Daiwa Bank Ltd. apparently violated Federal and New York State regulations, banking lawyers say. But whether it will face punishment beyond a requirement to improve its internal controls is unclear.

title: Too High a Price
description: Right now, it would be worth a great deal to end the war between Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the New York City schools system. But it is not worth making Leon Goldstein chancellor.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TASLIMA NASRIN, the Bangladeshi writer who has been in exile since a warrant for her arrest was issued last year accusing her of defaming Islam, came to New York this week, still vowing not to be silenced.

title: Sniper Is Sentenced for '94 Shootings in Which a Man Died
description: With his victims detailing their pain and loss, the sniper who terrorized Long Island last year was sentenced to 35 years to life in prison today.

title: Surge in Ad Revenue For TV Predicted
description: The Television Bureau of Advertising said yesterday that it expected significant increases for television advertising revenue in 1996, citing the Summer Olympics, the Presidential election and a "a reasonably healthy" economy.

title: Liberties; Grand Funk Railroad
description: "I like your pin," President Clinton said, pointing to my marcasite brooch. "Where'd you get it?"

title: Negotiators, Arab and Israeli, Built Friendship From Mistrust
description: There was a moment in the final, crisis-ridden hours of the negotiations on the West Bank that brought home to the heads of both the Israeli and the Arab teams what they had really achieved in their long months together.

title: A Third-Party Quest: The First Hurdle Is the Hardest
description: Getting on the Presidential ballot in California as a third-party candidate through the petition method has historically been so daunting that the last person to try was Henry Wallace in 1947. He made it, but just barely, and it took him six months.

title: Marcus Corp.(MCS,N) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Aug 17
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $ 14,815,000, or $ 1.12 a share, from the June 30, 1995 sale of the company's 18 Applebee's Neighborhood Grill and Bar restaurants and related real estate and franchise rights.The decline in the first quarter revenues was due to a reduction of $ 12 million in restaurant division revenues primarily resulting from the sale of the Applebee's restaurants and the leasing of the company's 11 Marc's Cafe and Coffee Mill restaurants to a management group.The results included 12 weeks of operations.

title: Take Supplies To Mass Sites, City Advises
description: New York City officials offered a few words of advice yesterday: Everyone planning to see the Pope should bring food and drink, and everyone coming to Manhattan for any reason next week should not bring their cars.

title: ALCATEL PLANS $2 BILLION REORGANIZATION
description: Alcatel Alsthom S.A. yesterday announced a first-half loss of more than $250 million and said it planned a $2 billion reorganization. The company, the largest European maker of telecommunications equipment, plans to sell secondary businesses over two years. The move is the first by Alcatel's new chairman, Serge Tchuruk, to turn around the troubled giant. The company reported a loss of 1.23 billion French francs for the first six months of 1995, or $250.5 million at current exchange rates, compared with a profit of 2.02 billion francs, or $411.4 million, in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: Celebrating an Instrument in a Night of Guitar
description: "New York Guitars," a new recording released recently by CRI, posits the existence of a New York school of avant-garde guitarists. An argument can be made for the school's existence, but the 10 tracks, and the nine guitarists who appeared at CBGB's 313 Gallery on Tuesday night to celebrate the release of the album, don't make the case.

title: Renovations On Erie Canal Get Approval
description: Despite concerns repeatedly raised by Gov. George E. Pataki, a state committee today gave final approval to a $146 million plan to revive recreational travel along the Erie Canal by adding small-boat piers, bicycle paths, hiking trails, outdoor cafes and other amenities.

title: Space Shuttle Is Set for 16-Day Research Flight
description: One of the longest space shuttle missions, a planned 16-day flight to conduct research in fluid physics, materials science and biotechnology, is set to get under way on Thursday morning.

title: With No Place to Run, Giants Brace for 49ers
description: When a tiger is resting quietly in its cage, it is not smart to jab a stick at it. Or, at the very least, run away after doing it. The Detroit Lions on Monday night gave the San Francisco 49ers a stick to the midsection. Now the 49ers will be looking to lash back, and it just so happens the Giants are standing in front of the cage.

title: Shift at Top: Du Pont Gets A New Chief
description: The Du Pont Company said yesterday that John A. Krol will become its chief executive at the end of the year, replacing Edgar S. Woolard Jr., who will remain as chairman.

title: Merger to Aid Desegregation Is Denounced
description: The Leonia High School gymnasium is called the Lion's Den after the school symbol, and it must have seemed like one tonight for three state officials gathering reaction to a court-ordered plan to desegregate the schools in nearby Englewood by busing in children from Leonia.

title: Essay; New Evil Empire
description: Security will be especially tight at the House Judiciary Committee's hearing room tomorrow morning, as a former Chicago mobster testifies about the penetration of organized crime into the booming world of "legitimate" gambling.

title: Congressional Roundup; Two Chairmen Fail to Gain Committees' Support for Major Changes in Farm Policy
description: A serious crack appeared today in the facade of Republican unity as the chairmen of the House and Senate Agriculture Committees both failed to persuade their colleagues to back measures that would make the broadest changes in American farm policy since the Depression.

title: Cavaliers Trade Price to Bullets
description: MARK PRICE, a four-time All-Star point guard and the National Basketball Association's career leader in free-throw accuracy, was traded to the Washington Bullets yesterday for a 1996 first-round draft pick.

title: Cintas Corp.(CTAS,NNM) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Aug 31
Timothy Jenkins, Met Tenor, Is Dead at 44
description: Timothy Jenkins, a tenor who sang at the Metropolitan Opera for more than a decade, died on Thursday in Durham, N.C. He was 44 and lived in Amarillo, Tex.

title: Auditors Can't Catch All Corporate Rogues
description: To the Editor:

title: Prince Is Bad, Rat-Catcher Polite
description: Unlike many a film that adults deem good for children, "Prince Brat and the Whipping Boy" is actually something children might want to see. It has a brisk pace, a storybook look, a bad-boy prankster and enough cheerful mischief to keep small fry in the audience happily occupied.

title: Dress Barn Inc.(DBRN,NNM) reports earnings for 4th qtr to July 29
No Plea Deal Struck in Case Of Informant
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it had not struck a plea agreement with Mark E. Whitacre, the former executive with the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company who became an informant in a Federal investigation of possible price-fixing at the company.

title: Mary, Mary, You're Turning Into Quite a Lou Grant
description: A Manhattan warehouse explodes and goes up in flames, killing a veteran firefighter as a journalist watches in horror. In the newsroom of The New York Reporter, the managing editor is shouting at an intern that he wants 500 words on body piercing by 5 o'clock. The paper's gossip columnist, a sort of Cindy Adams in "Terminator 2" mode, arrives with a black eye, wailing indignantly that her Asian taxi driver "crashed his cab while I was in it." Welcome to E.N., emergency newsroom. The new series begins tonight on CBS under the title "New York News."

title: American Homestar Corp. reports earnings for 1st qtr to Aug 31
TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League FLORIDA MARLINS -- Purchased the contracts of Jeff Alkire, pitcher, and Doug O'Neill, outfielder, from St. Paul of the Northern League. Assigned Alkire and O'Neill to Portland of the Eastern League.

title: Eco-Ideas Make Waves With Style
description: WHEN Surain and Robert afSandeberg bought the place, it was a dark, cramped sty where the former tenants nurtured snakes, turtles, dogs and tropical birds.

title: Philharmonic Negotiators Stay at Table
description: The musicians and management of the New York Philharmonic resumed negotiations on Tuesday and negotiated all day yesterday in the hope of averting a strike, threatened by the musicians for tonight.

title: President Casinos Inc.(PREZ,NNM) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss, which included charge of $ 4,053,000 from the exchange of subordinated notes.(Loss)

title: Time Warner to Sell Stake in Rap Label
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it would sever its ties to Interscope Records, the Los Angeles label whose gangsta rap performers plunged the giant media company into a politically charged controversy over violent and sexually degrading lyrics.

title: Agents Raid Production Lines in Queens for Fake Labels
description: In raids on factories, warehouses and shops in New York City and Los Angeles, customs agents attacked a Korean organized crime ring that manufactured clothing, handbags and sporting goods overseas for sale here under counterfeit labels.

title: International Briefs; Hoechst Sells a Stake In SGL Carbon
description: Hoechst A.G. said yesterday that it had sold a 23 percent stake in SGL Carbon A.G. for about 61 percent more than it would have received at the unit's first share sale in April. Hoechst sold 4.85 million shares in the carbon and graphite unit at 88.50 marks, or $61.76, each, bringing Hoechst's yield in the sale to 429.3 million marks. Hoechst retains 50 percent and one share in SGL.

title: Fuller (H.B.) Co.(FULL,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 2 million, or 14 cents a share, from the reversal of profit-sharing accrual.

title: CellStar Corp.(CLST,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
A Pooh Exhibition To Hum About
description: THE World of Pooh," an exhibition that opens today for a six-month run at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, is a cheery paean to A. A. Milne's classic Winnie-the-Pooh stories and poems, some of which are now 71 years old.

title: Vallen Corp.(VALN,NNM) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Aug 31
description: Vallen attributed its improved earnings in the latest quarter to improved distribution operations sales and earnings on comparable operations.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Big East Conference

title: Slayings Point to Serial Killer, Police Say
description: Concerned that a serial killer may be on the loose, the police announced yesterday that detectives have linked the strangulation murders of two prostitutes and the sexual assault of a third prostitute in Manhattan this year to a single attacker.

title: Japan Panel Urges Reform Of Nation's Bank System
description: In an effort to clear up the bad-loan problem that is threatening Japan's financial system, the Government moved today toward establishing an institution similar to the Resolution Trust Corporation, which was used to deal with the savings and loan crisis in the United States.

title: A New Nation's First P.O.W.'s
description: It was a routine inspection of a decrepit structure in a city park, but it brought back an ugly, all but forgotten episode in America's fight for independence. At the base of a monument in Brooklyn's Fort Greene Park, a municipal blacksmith opened a crypt containing the bones of more than 11,000 heroes who died on British prison ships in New York harbor.

title: Irish Peace Won't Come at Point of a Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: GIULIANI DEFENDS CHOICE FOR CHANCELLOR In an intensified defense of his latest choice of Leon M. Goldstein to be New York City's schools chancellor, Mayor Giuliani called criticism of Mr. Goldstein's political connections and qualifications "cheap shots and misinterpretations." [ Page A1. ] On campus and off, his critics say, Leon M. Goldstein plays all the political angles. [ B8. ] There are times, given the public's notoriously short memory, when a history lesson is in order. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [ B8. ] NEW YORK CITY CHESS PASSION WHIPS THE BLOOD This is the week the bloodthirsty chess world has been waiting for. After eight consecutive draws between the world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, and the challenger, Viswanathan Anand -- an unprecedented streak of standoffs -- the men traded victories. [ B3. ] SLAYINGS POINT TO SERIAL KILLER Concerned that a serial killer may be on the loose, the police announced that detectives have linked the strangulation murders of two prostitutes and the sexual assault of a third prostitute to a single attacker. [ B3. ] KOREAN GROCER KILLED IN FAILED HOLDUP An immigrant's dream was shattered when a robber shot him once in the stomach with a shotgun inside a delicatessen in Far Rockaway, Queens. [ B3. ] INDICTMENTS IN SCHOOL ASBESTOS CASE An environmental consulting company, its president and its laboratory director have been indicted on larceny and fraud charges for falsely certifying that a school in Woodside, Queens, had been cleared of asbestos, the Manhattan District Attorney said. [ B3. ] New York City officials say everyone planning to see the Pope should take food and drink and everyone coming to Manhattan for any reason next week should not bring their cars. [ B2. ] A New Jersey businessman fingered on videotape by a dead accomplice 13 years after a grisly Chelsea murder was sentenced to a minimum of 20 years in prison. [ B4. ] REGION WHITMAN DENIES FORCING AIDE OUT The Governor of New Jersey boasts in a speech that turning the Department of Motor Vehicles' district offices over to private management is working. The spokesman for the Department of Motor Vehicles bluntly contradicts her. The next day, the spokesman is dismissed. Was it spite or just the bungled ouster of a hapless employee? [ B6. ] EX-ESSEX OFFICIAL GUILTY IN KICKBACKS The former Register of Essex County pleaded guilty to accepting kickbacks and conspiring to use her influence as a director of a low-income housing complex to award millions of dollars in contracts to security guard companies. [ B6. ] CONVICTED KILLER ADMITS SLAYING WOMAN In a move that surprised even his own lawyer, Reginald McFadden pleaded guilty to murder, telling a Nassau County judge that he killed a 78-year-old woman in a rage after he got lost walking to a railroad station. [ B6. ] A state committee in Albany gave final approval to a $146 million plan to revive recreational travel along the Erie Canal by adding small-boat piers, bicycle paths, hiking trails, outdoor cafes and other amenities. [ B6. ] With his victims detailing their pain and loss, the sniper who terrorized Long Island was sentenced to 35 years to life in prison. [ B5. ]

title: Midpriced Hotels Look Abroad
description: For decades, American luxury hotel chains like Hilton and Hyatt have been familiar sights in foreign capitals and resorts, homes away from home for top business executives and well-heeled travelers.

title: The Victim Gets the Blame in Central Park
description: I fit the victim's description almost exactly. The early reports said that she was in her 30's (it turned out she was 44), average height, average build, Hispanic. She was dragged from the same bend in the road that I had glided down hundreds of times on my skates. Her arms and hands bore lacerations from her struggle to stay alive, a desperate battle I could easily imagine fighting.

title: Garden Q. &A.;
description: Drought's Consequences

title: Orders for Durable Goods Surged by 4.9% in August
description: Orders for big-ticket manufactured goods jumped 4.9 percent in August, the largest increase in a year, as some auto plants resumed production after a shutdown to retool for 1996 models, the Commerce Department said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A listings guide employs guerrilla tactics to find a niche in New York.
description: TIME OUT inside and outside the subways. Time Out on construction sites. Time Out on college campuses. Time Out in commuter rail stations.

title: Biology Is Not Destiny
description: Since the 1970's, science has become a battleground for contested values in our society, with clashes over everything from fetal research and the risks of recombinant DNA research to the teaching of evolution. Americans prize efficiency, yet value public participation. We insist on individual autonomy, yet expect social order. We value scientific knowledge, yet fear the influence of scientific thinking on our beliefs.

title: Folk-Art Award Winners Are Honored
description: A White House ceremony to honor the winners of the 1995 National Heritage Fellowship Awards yesterday turned into a concert that had the guests, including Hillary Rodham Clinton, on their feet, clapping along to the gospel music of Clarence Fountain and the Blind Boys of Alabama.

title: Domesticating Fiber-Optic Lights
description: FIBER-OPTIC lighting, which has been in commercial use in the United States for about 10 years, is now being introduced for homes. It is not only very energy efficient, but also a safe way to illuminate gardens, swimming pools (above) and other places where moisture is a problem. Because it generates no heat and filters out ultraviolet rays, it is perfect for lighting valuable artwork.

title: Pataki, a Son of Hungary, Is Embraced as Its Rich Uncle
description: The Prime Minister suggested on Monday that the Governor could help create an American Marshall Plan for Hungary. The Interior Minister asked him on Tuesday to help the nation fight organized crime. The mayor of one small town asked him for help in getting an airport, while the mayor of another thought Mr. Pataki might drum up investors for a riverside resort project.

title: Lintas Shops Get A Johnson Account
description: Johnson & Johnson has named Ammirati & Puris/Lintas in New York and its sibling, Lintas Worldwide, to handle its consolidated worldwide personal products business. Though the billings on the account, for brands like Stayfree pads and O.B. tampons, were not disclosed, Adweek estimated the worldwide business at $40 million to $50 million.

title: Conference Upsets Arts Groups
description: Officials of arts groups say they are upset that the New Jersey State Council on the Arts is spending $266,000 on a three-day conference this week while their groups are having difficulty staying afloat.

title: Russia's Soul Lives On in Cathedral
description: To the Editor:

title: Mean Season Starts With One-Upmanship
description: So now we are trapped in the Mean Season: Just when we want to be rooting for Don, Troy and Buster's kid, here come Steinbrenner, Jones and King to blot out the sun. It is the mean-spirited nature of sports entrepreneurs not only to exploit their boy toys, but also to snatch their glory.

title: Girl, 16, Is Accused of Throwing Her Newborn Baby to Her Death
description: No one knew Geneva Dickerson, 16, was pregnant. In fact, she told police investigators that she didn't know it herself. Throughout the summer, she wore baggy clothes and hung with friends in the hallways and around the courtyard of their sprawling housing project in Queens.

title: Tapping and Rapping Through the Night
description: Because the tiny Alterknit Theater at the Knitting Factory looks like a cabaret or coffeehouse rather than a conventional theater, it was wise of Karen Bernard and Jane Goldberg to present solos that resembled informal revue sketches when they danced there on Tuesday night.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about Dorothy Dickson, a former musical comedy star, referred incompletely to one survivor. She is the actress Jenny Quayle, a granddaughter.

title: J. B. Calhoun, 78, Researcher On Effects of Overpopulation
description: Dr. John B. Calhoun, an ecologist who saw in the bleak effects of overpopulation on rats and mice a model for the future of the human race, died on Sept. 7 while on vacation in Hanover, N.H. He was 78 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Corrections
